https://www.thetimes.com/culture/theatre.title: Hugo Ticciati: the fiddler who got the trees to talk
https://www.thetimes.com/culture/theatre.text:
David Attenborough could not have arranged it better. A chorus of birdsong bursts down the Zoom call. The beaming, Harry-Potterish face of Hugo Ticciati, one of classical musicâs most endearing eccentrics, looms into view. âLook at this,â he says, and swivels his computer so I get a panorama of trees, endless trees, massed in what seems like an impenetrable forest.
âIs that where you live?â I ask, looking out at my own domestic vista: the backyards of Kilburn, north London. âYes,â Ticciati replies. âIn the middle of the Swedish forest. By myself. For 21 years. Basically, I met the Russian violinist Nina Balabina in London when I was 19, and she gave me such an inspirational violin lesson that I thought, âI have to go where she is.â She happened to teach in Sweden, so I gave up a place at Cambridge University, bought myself a one-way ticket and have stayed here ever since.â
For the first few years he lived like a musical Trappist monk, spending his days in solitude â meditating, reading, thinking and practising the violin. Then ten years ago he founded a festival and an orchestra, both called O/Modernt, in the charming rococo Ulrikdals Palace Theatre, just north of Stockholm. The name O/Modernt (which Ticciati likes to be written with a backwards âeâ in the middle) simply means âun-modernâ, although nothing with Ticciati is quite that straightforward.
âItâs called un-modern because itâs a festival of new music taking place in an 18th-century theatre,â he says, âand because we try to awaken a new form of listening in our audiences. However, thereâs also a subliminal reference in the title to âomâ, the beginning of the Indian mantra evoking the creation of the world, the primordial sense of vibration. And the backwards âeâ is like the ego returning to primordial sound.â
Ticciati pauses, perhaps because of the bemused look on his interviewerâs face. âDonât worry,â he says soothingly. âThose are supposed to be hidden references.â
Hidden references and all, the spirit of O/Modernt comes to England this week when Ticciati curates, directs and is the solo violinist in what promises to be a concert like no other at the Manchester International Festival. In it we will be plunged back into those forests, metaphorically anyway, because the concert (played by the pioneering Manchester Camerata) is called The Patience of Trees.
Thatâs also the title of the main piece, a new violin concerto by Dobrinka Tabakova, a British-Bulgarian composer whose work Ticciati often champions. âBy coincidence, we found we had both been reading about the life of trees, and immediately thought this would be a great idea for a new piece,â Ticciati says. âWe were both struck by the notion, which grew out of the pandemic, that trees stand for centuries, with huge, self-possessed patience, through the changing seasons and all sorts of wild weather.â
As usual with Ticciati, however, the metaphor is more elaborate than it first seems. âThe tree is solitary, but then you stand back and see it in a network of trees, a forest,â he elaborates. âThen you read about what scientists call the âwood-wide webâ: the idea of all their roots forming a huge network, allowing trees to communicate with each other under the soil.â
I sense thereâs an analogy looming, and Iâm not wrong. âItâs just like human relationships,â he exclaims. âWe can all seem solitary and alienated. Heaven knows, the pandemic has shown us that. Yet the deeper you dig into your roots, into yourself, the more the interconnections with everyone else become apparent.â
How is all this expressed in music, without any text? âIt starts as a very lonely violin solo, rather folk-like in character, then gradually the other instruments join in, and at the end we return to the solitary soloist, but with a sense that we are all connected,â Ticciati says. âSo we are taken on a journey of inner discovery.â
Thatâs just one item in a programme of shortish pieces (all by living composers) that Ticciati hopes will explore âthe relationship, or conflict, between nature and the cityâ. Steve Reichâs New York Counterpoint represents the city in this mix. âWe will have its electronics surrounding the audience, so they will be immersed in a sonic landscape that is trance-like,â Ticciati says.
I bet that has some metaphorical significance too. âWell, yes,â he replies. âFor me, people living in cities are in a state of unconsciousness. Existing day after day in the same routine, on the same treadmill, they lose all sense of a living reality. For me, Reichâs piece perfectly depicts that. Itâs the antithesis of nature, which is continually changing.â
Even the presentation of the concert will be charged with symbolism, Ticciati promises. âThe audience, sitting in a circle, will basically be the roots of the tree. Then we, the musicians, will walk in humming â creating the rustling of the branches.â
If he were not a musician, would Ticciati be some sort of eco-activist â manning the Extinction Rebellion barricades, for instance? âThereâs a danger in activism because itâs often ego-driven and ends in violence,â he replies. âThe cause for which the activists are campaigning may be 100 per cent correct â we all know we are messing up the Earth â but we have seen through history how easily a good cause is turned into something that destroys. The greatest form of activism is listening in silence. If we all listened to nature, we wouldnât need activists.â
Ticciati comes from a fairly privileged English background. The brother of the conductor Robin Ticciati, Glyndebourneâs music director, he is a product of St Paulâs School in Hammersmith, London, and a violin prodigy who made various startling debuts at the age of 12. The conjuring trick he has pulled off since his mid-twenties is ostensibly to reject a conventional soloistâs career, yet build one anyway â on his own terms.
âI have been so blessed,â he says, with a saintly smile to match.
He has premiered dozens of violin works written specially for him. Is he aiming to overtake Mstislav Rostropovichâs record for first performances (âI lost count at 200,â the great Russian cellist told me). âI think Iâve got a long way to go to catch up with Rostropovich, in almost every way,â Ticciati laughs.
Besides, heâs a radically different person. He still meditates every day, as he has for 20 years. âI have dipped my toes into every meditating technique known to humanity,â he says. âSo I concoct my own little cocktail depending on my mood each morning.â
And he is still in love with his fiddle. âI am one of those people who, if someone said, âYouâve got a free day to do anything you want,â would spend it meditating and practising the violin. The sheer joy of trying to master my instrument, which I will never do, will stay with me till I die.âThe Patience of Trees is at Manchester Central, July 16 (mif.co.uk)
